title: How Nick Cave's wife captured hearts and minds with needle and thread
text:
Cave founded the label almost on a whim, in 2014, naming it after a half-written novel by her husband. “The initial idea for The Vampire’s Wife was not ‘planned’ at all, beyond making some dresses for my friends,” she says.

Cave says her clothes have "a kind of subversive mystery" to them. Lauren Joy Fleishman

But the dresses were evidently special, and requests began pouring in. “The demand for the dresses just keeps growing and we are frantically running to keep up with the expansion of the brand,” she says.

Typically, a designer in her position would team up with a luxury fashion conglomerate or, at the very least, a deep-pocketed investor. But Cave says she has no interest in such a move. She still designs everything herself, in her modest atelier in the seaside town of Brighton. The Vampire’s Wife does not hold runway shows and Cave simply releases new collections when they are ready (her latest came out in August).

My dresses feel like ghost-like memories and fever-dreams that re-connect me to the world. — Susie Cave

“Our strategy is to remain authentic and real and to work at my own pace,” she says. “Ultimately, I need to love my work, and the way to do that is to stay intimately connected to the dresses and the designs by doing small production runs.”

For Cave, this approach is about more than creative fulfilment: in July 2015, just as The Vampire’s Wife was taking flight, her 15-year-old son Arthur died in a fall from a cliff in Brighton.

Now, she says, “work is simply a matter of survival. It has literally saved my life. It has momentum and flow, and it feels like I am creating a parallel universe that exists beyond the trauma of the loss of my son. To sit and dream and design a dress and to watch it grow into something is a source of great joy for me.”

"Our strategy is to remain authentic," says Cave of the label's small production runs.

She adds: “My dresses feel like ghost-like memories and fever-dreams that reconnect me to the world.”

Advertisement

In the wake of Arthur’s death, Susie, Nick and their surviving son, Earl, contemplated leaving Brighton. But, for now, they remain. “Brighton will always feel like home,” Cave explains. “It is so beautiful – all that lovely late-afternoon coral-coloured light and the sparkling sea. But it is a town full of sadness for me and sometimes I need to get away. We tend to head to LA – a very different kind of place.”

Cave also spends time on the road with her husband, who has played some of the best-received concerts of his career in recent years and has just released a two-part album, Ghosteen, an achingly beautiful meditation on loss and survival. “The songs on the first album are the children. The songs on the second album are the parents. Ghosteen is a migrating spirit,” he writes on his website.

The cover for Nick Cave's new album, available digitally now and out on vinyl and CD on November 8. VMPR

“These are probably the most painful songs Nick Cave and The Bad Seeds have ever recorded,” the British music website NME wrote, “but they’re also the most beautiful: it is a work of extraordinary, unsettling scope.”

Together, the couple makes plans for the fashion label’s future.

“My husband is very involved,” Cave says. “You know, he just loves clothes – especially women’s clothes. He has an intuitive understanding of what looks good on a woman, so I run a lot of designs by him.

“He acts as a kind of beauty barometer. He is at his happiest flicking through a swatch of fabric.”

NEED TO KNOW

The new collection is available at Brown’s, Net-A-Porter and from thevampireswife.com
description: Susie Cave reflects on the runaway success of The Vampire’s Wife fashion label, the brand she founded in 2014 “to make some dresses for my friends”.
